Award.AwardTitle: Limit Shapes from a Combinatorial Viewpoint
Award.AbstractNarration:
How does water turn into ice? How does a collection of iron atoms gain or lose magnetic properties with changes in temperature? "Statistical mechanics" is the branch of mathematics and physics which deals with understanding such systems: systems consisting of large numbers of identical objects, interacting locally. The main goals of statistical mechanics are to describe large-scale behavior and phase transitions through mathematical methods. One of the most interesting and important types of behavior is when an external force, such as an imposed boundary condition or other constraint, results in a non-homogeneity in the resulting ensemble. A simple example of this is the water/ice transition under a pressure gradient induced by gravity. The principal investigator proposes to study mathematical models of such behavior in a variety of basic settings, in hopes of understanding their common features and to be able to predict similar behavior in other potentially more complex systems.

The notion of limit shape in probability describes the property of large random systems to settle into a fixed, nonrandom state in the limit of large system size. Typically limit shapes arise due to a combination of entropic considerations and energy minimization. Several diverse areas where limit shapes have been shown to arise are in the theory of random graphs with subgraph density constraints, random tilings with imposed boundary conditions, and random configurational models such as "square ice." These examples are all studied through variational formulations. By studying their common features the PI hopes to learn more about the limit shape phenomenon in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many random process involving a large number of small components take on a specific, well-defined and non-random shape in the limit of large system size, called limit shape; for example a well-known case of limit shape is the bell curve coming from a large number of coin tosses.

We studied limit shapes arising in random tilings and related models. These limit shapes are surfaces, which, like soap-bubble surfaces, satisfy certain energy minimization constraints, with an energy function which depends on both the underlying parameters and the entropy of the random model. Unlike soap bubble surfaces, however, our surfaces can develop facets and other singularities as the parameters vary. Understanding how these singularities form and how they illuminate the behavior of the underlying random model is an important mathematical problem.

We worked on several random models, one related to electrical networks and graph colorings, and another related to the ``square ice'' model. We gave explicit formulations of the limit shape problem and showed that the limit surfaces are quite explicitly parameterized by analytic functions.

This work enhances our knowledge of limit shapes in general but we were also able to connect it with other areas of math such as conformal field theory, which is the underlyong geometry of string theory. Indeed, we discovered relations between a quite general limit shape problem and the underlying (and previously hidden) conformal geometry of the random surface model.
